Name: N30: We Are Winning – The Battle of Seattle
Description:
A game of the "Battle of Seattle" in 1999. Two players, 11x17" map, 168 counters. 13 pages of rules & 7 of notes. This is a complete redesign of N30 I and N30 II at a more detailed scale.

"N30 portrays the morning blockades of November 30th. Two players represent the opposing sides; one represents protesters; the other represents the police, with their incident commanders, Assistant Chief Ed Joiner and Captain Jim Pugel. The protesters aim to show that non-violent direct action can work, show that networked organizations can defeat hierarchical ones, and bring media attention to the issues. The police try to break the blockades and allow the conference to open as planned."

"Each turn represents 10 minutes. Each protester cluster represents 20-30 protesters, of whom 10-15 may be arrestables; each police hard or soft squad represents 10-15 police; each police mounted squad represents 6 police and each police chemical team represents 4 police (usually with 1 armored car). The police forces include most of the units of the Demonstration Management Team. They also include squads scrambled from the Convention Center venue (and/or other police units in the area)."

Name: Gimme Five
Description: Game consists of all players being dealt hands of standard playing cards and upon their turn placing a counter on a board (which simply shows all the faces in a card deck twice over) square corresponding to a card in their hand. Game is won when 3 'convoys' (five counters of one color in a row in any direction) of the same color are formed on the board.

Name: Schmetterlingskind: wach auf geschwind
Description:
Content:
board, 12 butterflies in 4 colors, 40 sun beams, 1 cloud, 1 special die

After a long and cold night the butterfly must awake. The sun rises. When a sun beam reaches a sleeping butterfly, he awakes and flies to a flower. The player who waked up all three own butterflies wins the game.

Name: Frenzy
Description: Six steel balls roll down a vertical board to land in various scoring bins at the bottom.  A wind-up mechanism releases them individually onto the topmost of a series of steps that you tilt manually.  The longer you can control a ball's descent to land on more steps without rolling off into the gutters, the more points it scores.  But don't spend too much time concentrating on one ball because the next one will drop at any second.  As you become more proficient, you can shorten the time between balls from Beginner to Expert.

Name: Olympic Challenge: The Boardgame
Description:
From the publisher: "Take the Olympic Trivia Challenge and play through the Olympic 5 Rings. Test your knowledge while competing with family and friends. Learn how the Olympic movement inspires everyone around the world in friendly competition. Feature categories include: Athletes, Countries, Events, Olympic History, and Rules and Records."

Set includes game board, question and answer cards, medal cards, die and 5 playing pieces.  For 2 to 20 players.  
Purchase supports US Olympic team.  Ages 12 and up

Name: Flip Flop Freezer Pops
Description:
An Ice chest full of color matching and memory fun!

Open the cooler to color-matching chills and thrills! kids Try to match freezer Pop Cards to the Ice Cube Die after its dropped through the Ice Machine dice roller while building memory skills.

2 levels of play forAges 3 - 7 with no reading required.

Name: Dudenkönig
Description:
Content:
German dictionary "Duden", board,36 cards, 6 pawns, 6 counting stones, 1 die, 1 sand watch

When the players reach certain fields after throwing the die and moving, they have to fulfill different games around words and characters.
The player who won the most points and reaches the top most step of the stairs will be "Duden-King"

Name: Roll Over Rover
Description:
The color matching game with the tumbling pup!

The die in this game is a large colorful puppy. You roll the puppy to see what color you move to. You can connect the paths to make the game as long or as short as you like. The paths are also double sided to provide 2 levels of play for both beginner and advanced players. Ages 3 - 7 with no reading required.

Name: Grand Canyon Adventure Board Game
Description:
From the box and website description:

"Experience the adventure! Be the first player to collect photos from eight Grand Canyon destinations in this exciting game of strategy, luck, and adventure. Roll the dice to advance on the river and trails, racing your family and friends. Use your gear and test your fate as you learn more about the Grand Canyon as you play."

Name: Huskeropoly
Description:
Monopoly style game based on the University of Nebraska

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: Herbie Husker, Memorial Stadium, Love Library, and Nebraska Union

Name: FSUopoly
Description:
Monopoly like game based on Florida State University.

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: College Avenue, Lake Bradford, Seminole Marching Band, The Phyrst, Sweet Shop, Landis, and University Union.

Name: Cycloneopoly
Description:
Monopoly-like game based on the Iowa State University.

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: Union Drive, Cy, Reiman Gardens, Memorial Union, and Hilton Coliseum.

Name: Headline Deadline
Description:
(from box back)

If you've ever read the newspaper or a magazine, listened to the radio or watched TV, you're sure to be a winner in Headline Deadline, the game where a little general knowledge goes a long way!

It's an outrageous game of strategy and insanity as headlines are read out loud and your teammates start yelling out related facts at a furious pace. But the seconds are flying by as you try to write down as many facts as your hand allows - all within a 30 second DEADLINE!

Oh, no! Time's up and the correct matches have to be tallied before you can move along the track, rolling and racing towards the finish. But was that your sweetheart's fact you forgot to write down? Geez! You'll never hear the end of it!!!

Name: Electro Quizzman
Description: This game exists out of 2 books (an expansion of 2 other books came as well). You place the book in the electronic device "computer" and put in the code of the page you want to play. Now you get trivia questions about the subject on the page of the book. This game can be played with two as well as alone. The electronic device is there, just to see whether you gave the right answer and to remember your scores.

Name: Solobridge
Description:
From front of the box:

The Real Bridge Game - Using Real Cards - Which You Play By Yourself

The Fun Way To Bid And Play Better

Learn And Improve You Game Guided By Experts

Included 50 Prepared Hands

For Beginners And Intermediate Players

Name: Mensch ärgere Dich nicht: Das 3-Dreh-Spiel
Description:
The board has a hexagonal basic area on which 5 levels are put together to a pyramid.
The segments of the pyramid can be turned during the game.
It is important to bring 3 or 4 own pawns out of the game.
A pawn is taken out of the game when there is only one pawn on a level.

Contents:
1 board
60 pawns
1 die

Name: EcoRanch
Description: The game is set on a ranch that takes in abused and neglected animals. The players are volunteers who adopt an animal and try to herd animals to the foster pens while caring for all their needs. In the process, players have to make choices, either just do the work, or stop and help others with theirs, which earns enlightened point chips. The winner of the game has the most of those.

Name: 54 Jones: Keeping up with the Joneses
Description:
In 54 Jones the Baord Game, you play clones of sewer worker 54 Jones on a training day in the sewers of subterranean 12 Station City.  However, 54 Jones unleashes a tidal wave of 'shunk' to try and drown the competition.  The first clone to reach high ground wins the game.

To reach high ground, each junior Jones clone must race along the sewer network, battling his fellow clones, shirkers, Cynthia and the endless ever changing labyrinth of tunnels. Players get the chance to rotate, lock and change tiles throughout the game.  Only the most calculating and devious clone will win.

The game is now available to buy from Rathbone Games and comes with boards, counters, dice and sewer denizens.

Name: Eprion
Description:
There is a place with no time or space, wandering on the eternity of an inexistent reality. The beginning of everything and the converge of nothing. Welcome a new era of fantasy, heroism and eternal battles. The Eprion era.

In a very distant world called Eprion, two races must face each other in a great battle. The game comes with two sets of cards and figures. The cards can be creatures or spells. Each creature card has an associated figure that can be played in the board. The board is composed by 6 modular boards which must be placed at the beginning of the game: forest, ice, desert, swamp, lake and plain. The position in which they are placed is very relevant, since the creatures abilities are affected by the kind of landscape they are standing in.
The object of the game is to be the first one in defeating the adversary’s leader, which is protected by 2 gemstones and his army.

Eprion is not just a game. It comes with a very well written book with the story of this world where you can learn about the story of almost every character of the game.

Name: Tankattack
Description:
This game advertises itself as "the first computer based Tank game in the world". It is a board game 'controlled' by an electronic handset which serves as a randomizer for combat actions. According to the instructions, the computer "has counters, gates, oscillator clock, programming, read out and execute functions. The 'brain' is made of three miniature TTL logic chips containing over 300 transistors, diodes, and many other components giving a vast computing capacity with a wide range of probabilities for conflict purposes."

In essence, this is a straightforward  hex-map based battle game for up to four players playing individually or as teams. It contains plastic miniatures and a rectangular game board with pre-marked battlefield features. There are no battle cards or other modifiers apart from the handset. The game depends entirely upon the handset to determine the amount of movement and the result of any attack. The handset therefore replaces dice, but serves much the same function. However, players have the freedom to select position, and direction of movement, and the miniatures are marked with values that determine their firing power, and this has a bearing on the result of combat actions (see below).

Each team deploys a regiment of 8 of tanks (slow moving, high fire power) and 4 armoured cars (fast moving, low fire power) in a pre-mapped fictive country on the game board (Kazaldis, Armania, Sarapan and Calderon) separated by marked national borders (which are red) and terrain features such as a river (with bridges), forests, mountains, and buildings. Each country also has a major city marked by a blue border. Inside the blue border several buildings are marked, into which tanks cannot move, meaning they must navigate the city to get to the enemy HQ or get out of their service/repair area and back into combat.

The objective is simple: to win by occupying the opponent or opponents' headquarters by moving a tank (or armoured car) into the HQ space (pre-marked on the board), or by destroying all enemy tanks.

Though the mechanic is therefore a fairly standard hex and counter skirmish, the computer in the handset ultimately drives the game.

The handset consists of six small red bulbs, two buttons and three switches. The lights appear over six icons indicating conditions of movement (the computer determines 'movement points' which may be spent according to terrain features - for example moving through a city costs one movement point per movement but armoured cars moving in open country may move two spaces per movement point), result of firing, repair status and range of attack.

The bulbs have three states - on, off, and flashing, each of which has a different meaning (see below). Of the three switches, one is a power switch. The other two switches determine the conditions of the 'roll' on any given player's turn. One indicates whether the player has opted to attack or retreat (the selection becomes a variable in the computer's calculation of the result), the other on whether the tank is moving or being repaired (tanks under repair cannot move or fire, but if the handset indicates that the service has been successful, the tank can move and fire in that turn).

The handset also has two buttons: one red, one black. The black button is pressed for between 2 and 5 seconds to command the computer to run a computation cycle that will determine movement and repair status (depending on the switches). It will also secretly determine a firing result that will be shown if and when the player presses the 'fire' button (firing is optional).

The red button is for firing. When a player wishes to fire, they press this button and the computer indicates the result of the firing action. If the bulb is fully lit, the result is a hit and the tank with the lower fire power is destroyed. In the case of equal firepower, the attacking tank is considered to have the advantage and destroys the defender. If the bulb flashes, the tank with the lower fire power is damaged and must be placed on a service space for repair. If the bulb stays dark, the attack has failed. According to the instructions "When the computer is programmed for Assault the 'firing result' probability is expressed as a 50% chance of a Hit, 25% chance of Damage and 25% chance of a Miss, while the chance of a 'Service Ready' is 25%. When the computer is programmed for Retreat the 'firing result' probability is expressed as a 25% chance of a Hit, 25% chance of Damage and 50% chance of a Miss, while the chance of 'service ready' is 25%."

Firing is further complicated by the game board and player actions though. A tank in open country can only fire at an enemy tank in a directly adjacent hex in front of or behind it, and it must turn to face in the direction it wishes to fire. Within city boundaries a tank may fire at an enemy in any hex in contact with the one it occupies, though it must again turn to face the target. Ranged firing (two spaces) is possible in open country, but is again a random result from the handset. A tank which is allowed a ranged attack by the handset may fire across lakes and rivers, but not mountains.

Name: Assault of the Ogroids
Description:
Assault Of The Ogroids is a computer moderated solo board game published in the May 1987 issue of Sinclair User magazine, a computer magazine for the 8-bit SInclair ZX Spectrum.

The player takes the part of Deerfoot, a scout sent to gain aid for his city which is being besieged by the evil Ogroids.  The board is a rectangle 12 spaces by 15 spaces, and the player wins the game by traveling across the board within 30 hours.

Every square entered takes a toll of the available time and the player's stamina.  There are five different types of terrain, and the random encounters include finding useful items, meeting unfriendly monsters, becoming lost or finding a quicker route to your eventual goal.  You lose once 30 game hours have passed, or if you are killed by a monster or other kind of encounter.

The computer program is approximately 90 lines of BASIC. It randomises numbers for combat and for encounters met along the way, and also keeps a track of the gold and items held by the player.

Gary Chalk designed the game and also illustrated it in a style familiar from the "Lone Wolf" game books.

Name: Di End
Description: Di End is very simple abstract game for 2 players. It could be played everywhere, every time, and could be played with chess or draughts (8x8) set. You've got 8 pawns each, all in 1. (or 8.) row. You must capture maximum possible number of opponents pawns in your turn. To win, you must capture all of opponents pawns or to move all your pawns which still are on the board to the last row. Ties are rare, but possible. You must pay attention, because it's possible to lose more than 5 pawns in one move, even if it doesn't look like. Easy to learn, hard (or maybe impossible) to perfect.

Name: Quartetto
Description:
The Quartetto is played on a common 8x8 checkerboard.

Each player has four checkers, each initially placed at the middle four board positions of the opposite rows.

Checkers are moved horizontally or vertically any number of unoccupied board positions. Game play alternates between the two players.

The goal of the game is to place all own checkers in board positions, which middle points are vertices of some rotated square (being non-parallel towards board edges). The smallest surrounding box of this constellation being parallel to edges of the board must be greater or equal 5x5 board positions.

Complete rules text in

     English
     German


Quartetto is closely related to and implements similar concepts of Adrian Schacker's Mondrago (1992) and John Scarne's Teeko (1945).




    
         Game

         Board Size

         Pawn moves like...

         Winning Condition: Pawns form a...

    
    
         Quartetto

         8x8

         Rook in Chess

         rotated square larger than defined minimum size

    
    
         Mondrago

         5x5

         King in Chess

         rotated and non rotated square (any size)

    
    
         Teeko

         5x5

         King in Chess

         straight line or non rotated square

Name: Fantasy Adventurers
Description:
This is a light weight 'filler' strategy game where you explore dungeons, kill things, take their stuff, return to town, heal your party, gain some levels, then start all over again with an even harder dungeon.

It's basically the stereotypical fantasy RPG done up as a strategy game where you manage a party of characters rather than role play a single character.

Fantasy Adventurers is designed to be a light, simple and quick two-player game that can be played almost anywhere, but includes rules for solo play and three players.

In addition to the game rules you will need a sheet of paper, something to write with and a single d20.

The game is only available as a PDF download and includes these PDF files: Adventurers Guide, Game Play Guide, Dungeon Builders Guide, and Character Sheets.

Name: Rapid 4 More
Description:
An evolution of the game "Rapid 4", "Rapid 4 More" sees players try to get four marbles in a row by dropping them into holes at the top of a vertical tray much like in Connect Four. The drop, however, is filled with levers that shift as the marble drops through them; players must drop marbles to shift the levers so as to drop marbles into scoring or blocking positions on the slotted gameboard below.

"Rapid 4 More" utilizes two boards instead of one, and introduces an element of negotiation between players -- block a winning opponent, make a move of one's own, or forgo moving altogether in order to block another.

http://www.uncleskunkle.com/

Name: Caught in the Web
Description: Children's game themed on insect knowledge.  Players play one of four insects (butterfly, bee, dragonfly, or grasshopper) and navigate the gameboard (depicting a spiderweb) by answering trivia questions about insects.  The first player to successfully make it through the web to return to his habitat is the winner.

Name: Defensores de la Tierra
Description:
Defenders of the Earth is an action and adventure game for adventurers of 9 years up.

One adventurers team made of the most famous comic heroes - The Phantom, Flash Gordon and Mandrake - to save the Earth supporting a titanic fight against Ming, the tyrannical monster lover of the intergalactic war, and his wicked schemes.

The game consists in the fight of superheroes against Ming, who is in Ice Station Earth, constructed under an arctic mountain, and to rescue the prisoners who are there.

Content:

- 1 board
- 42 cards
- 4 player pieces: 3 heroes (The Phantom, Flash Gordon and Mandrake) and the bad guy (Ming).
- 2 Dice
- 4 gamer pieces for the ice warriors
- 1 instructions

Name: A Game of Cats and Mice, The Lost Diamond, and Gantlope
Description: This is a turn-of-the-century board game published by the McLoughlin Brothers, and comprised of three distinct games: A Game of Cats and Mice, The Lost Diamond, and Gantlope. It has beautiful illustrations, and a double spinner component which seems to be made as an answer to negative stigma surrounding dice. The game folds up and double as a box for components.

Name: What Did I Step In?
Description:
From the publisher:
"Here is a crazy mixed-up matching memory game. Use the sneaker to step on a card - the suction-cup heel will pick it up! If the card you step on matches a card in your hand you get to keep the match. Players compete to collect the most, all the while trying to avoid the worst thing you can step in - dog poop! Contents: 21 Step-In cards, 28 Step-In squares, sneaker with built-in suction cup, game rules."

Name: Über den goldenen Steig
Description:
Game simulates the historian routes of the salt transport around the year of 1500.

Object of the game is to collect the components for a historical "Säumer-Zug" (salt transporting caravan) with horses, riders, accompanying soldiers and/or mercenaries to encounter the dangers of the voyage.
In the meantime you have to mine salt and to acquire food for your caravan.
If you think the time is right you begin your dangerous way from the Bavarian Woods to the equally dark Bohemian Forests in order to reach the Czech capitol of Prag the first and to achieve the highest prices for your salt.

The game is of outstanding component quality.
A wooden box, where the lid acts as one of 6 wooden game boards, 3 different sorts of metal coins, real crystals, small salt cans and other heavy metal game pieces (horseshoes, pawns etc.)are a joy to behold.

The game is a project of the profession schools of the German and Czech border regions Waldkirchen and Susice.

It is manufactured by special order only, delivery time over 6 months, as nearly every game component is hand-made.

Educational aspect is served as a Czech-German dictionary comes with the game as well as a historical booklet describing salt-mining and transporting of the time being.

Name: Bratz Charmed Life Game
Description:
From the publisher:

Be the first beautiful Bratz girl to make a round on the red carpet, answer questions from reporters, agents, fans and photographers and fill up her necklace with stylish and chic charms. The first player to reach superstar celeb status by collecting eight funky charms wins the game.

Game includes: red carpet backdrop game board, 4 molded BRATZ girl game pieces, 32 charms (8 per girl), 4 charm necklaces, 120 game cards (photo, press, agent and fan), 12 charmed cards, 16 multiple-choice letter cards, 4 yes/no cards and die.

Name: Marble Mania 3-D
Description:
From the publisher:
"Be the first to reach the finish line by climbing rickety ladders and avoiding slippery slides!

A truly unique 3-dimensional version of the classic children’s game! Players move their marbles along the board based on the roll of the die. If their marble lands on a space with a slide, gear, ladder or other challenging obstacle, they must test their skill! Contents include: 3-D game board, 4 colored marbles, number die."

Name: The Winning Touch
Description:
"A new exciting arithmetic fun game for all the family"

This very unusual multiplication game uses numbered tiles and a placement grid. The strategy is similar to Blokus... players use the tiles to match a multiplication fact BUT they must place each correct answer in a square touching another tile. The first player to empty his/her tile rack wins.

Includes board, four wooden racks, tiles, rules, and a vintage ad flier from the company.

(c)1962 Educational Fun Games P.O. Box 56 Winnetka, IL

Name: Angleside School Adventure: A Measurement Game
Description: Players explore geometry and measurement as they move around the game board (representing a round school) using a built-in compass. Game cards direct players to measure, compare and categorize angles. Players roll the die to move, draw a card if they land on a question space, and use the built-in compass to find the answer.  The winner is the first player to make it to the bus stop.

Name: Zahlenluchs
Description: Players place numbered tiles on the table. If they recognize certain mathematical patterns in the tiles on the table, they can put tokens on them. The player who can get rid of his or her tokens first, wins the game.

Name: Silly Expressions
Description:
It's fun with grins and frowns as the whole family gets into this nutty game. Match your face with your game cards for miles of smiles.

A children's game that has a player drawing a card with a funny expression on it. The player then has to match their expression with the one on the card (optionally using the provided mirror to make sure they have it right). The other players must look at the players face and try to find the expression on the game board.

Name: Strike
Description:
Strike! is a loosely based simulation of the British car industry of the 1970's and was published free in a 1981 edition of Games & Puzzles magazine.

Players are paired together and act as representatives of their respective car manufactures. Each of the pair takes on the role of managing director, the other as union leader of its' work force.

The role of the managing director is one of expanding sales and profits against competition from other managing directors in the rival car firms.

The role of the union leader is to secure fair deal for the workers and secure the highest possible share of the company profits against the resistance of the management.

Strike! asks you to do the impossible: combine with players holding diametrically opposite interests to achieve your objectives within the company while helping to sweep the competition from the market.

Name: Hand-Off: The Card Football Board Game
Description:
Hand-Off combines the strategy and decision making of playing cards with the drama and tension of college football. You take control of the action – bust out a big run, throw a game-breaking long bomb, make the big open-field tackle, or pick off the pass and take it the other way for a touchdown.

Hand-Off is a new and improved version of CSE Games' original critically-acclaimed Card Football: Premiere Edition game.

For one to four players, Hand-Off takes about 45 minutes to play and features the following editions (with more to come):

- Florida Gators
- LSU Tigers

Hand-Off also features Team Cards highlighting some of the best teams of all-time.

Bragging rights are on the line as players battle through four fast-paced quarters of Hand-Off action.

Name: Bunjee
Description: Bunjee is a simple dice rolling game with some risk management. Each player is playing a figure jumping from a tree, trying to fall low enough to reach the goal but not too low to avoid crashing on the floor. On his turn, the player launch the dies, hecks the result and decides to satisfy himself with the result of the dices or roll some dices again to better his score. Of course, re-rolling the dices includes some risk. Mechanism is very close to the Can't Stop from Sid Sackson.

Name: Hazar
Description:
The aim of the game is to win all 60 chips. Before playing starts the chips are given a certain value. It is allow just to play for the own honor.

From the designer:

In fact, Hazar is some kind of "Las Vegas in your pocket", played in Bars and Cafes, by groups having fun with losing or winning money... There are 60 steel-chips. Up to 12 players (5 chips each) put their chips on numbers in different combinations. The stakes are high, because, in the end, there is only one player, who wins the 60 chips.

Name: Company Commander
Description:
20TH and 21ST Century Skirmish Wargame Rules

These miniatures rules have the unique feature of, your side keeps going until you either fail at something, or the other side successfully interrupts your actions.

From the designer notes:
"The rules are designed to be used for World War Two, Korea, Vietnam and The Soviet-Afghan War. That does not mean that they can’t be used for other actions more current or further in the past. I know that some folks use them for World War One, The Spanish Civil War, The Falklands and current actions in Afghanistan and Iraq."

"I think that each player can handle a platoon to a Company. That might mean two platoons of infantry (about thirty to sixty infantry) and a platoon of Afv’s three to five strong. I really believe your table space will dictate how many toys you want to put on the table. A Company per side or less will probably run one to two hours to play."

Name: Panzer Korps:  Divisional Level Warfare 1936-1945
Description:
The basic unit is the battalion, usually comprised of three stands of infantry or three vehicles. The basic command formation would be (depending on nation/year) a Brigade or Division. Each Brigade/Division has an attached commander, and each side has a CinC stand. Commanders have Leadership ratings which influence initiative and the pace of the game. The overall rating of a formation determines which Decision Die (Activation) it uses, which determines how many units may act, how many auto-rallies you get, etc.
Units are rated by morale, which is the key element of the game. A unit's morale determines which attack die you use, which morale die you use, and how many times it can recover from panicking.

Fire Combat: The attacker must make an opposed die roll to hit and damage its target. The attacker rolls a die based upon its morale grade, so a Militia unit roles a d6 while an Elite unit roles a d12 to hit. The defender rolls a Cover Die based upon covering terrain; open (d4), light cover (d6), type of tank (light, Med. Heavy) etc. The difference determines how many disorder markers the target takes, and can force a Panic Check.

Attached companies provide fire support, and special units are important in the game. A unit can have up to four attached companies that provide Fire Die bonuses, help recover Disorder markers, etc. Example, a Battalion with an attached HMG company (+2), Mortar Company (+1), AA Company and Medical Company would get a +3 on its Fire Die, force attacking aircraft to make a Morale Check to press a ground attack, and automatically remove one Disorder Marker per turn.

The rules are fairly comprehensive and cover all the basics of the period -- air superiority over the battlefield, ground attack, artillery, smoke, amphibious landings, fortifications, mines, engineers, supply, paratroopers, gliders, etc.

Also included is a set of rules on generating battles and battlefield terrain, basic army lists, equipment lists, and some sample battles and campaigns.

(from the publisher's web site)

Expanded by:

    Panzer Korps: Campaigns â€“ Rules & Scenarios
Families: Series: Panzer Korps Miniature Wargame (Hoplite Research Games)

Name: Przeklęta Kopalnia
Description:
Przekleta Kopalnia (The Cursed Mine) is an adventure game about dwarves exploring an old mine. The dwarf who finds the treasure and leaves the mine with it is declared the winner. To find the treasure the dwarves have to use several items like a shovel, a lantern etc. To make the task harder the mine is haunted by a dangerous ghost which can steal the treasure from the dwarves or even force them to start their search from the beginning.

The mechanics are: a modular board changed by the players during play, and various powers the different characters possess.

Name: Wonka-Tonka
Description:
Content:
board, 6 Indians, 1 wooden feather container, 18 feather, 1 color die

Carefully the small Indians slide from totem pole to totem pole in order to get the prettiest feather from the hiding place. But pay attention - another Indian may sneak a feather away from you. Who will catch the most feathers?

Name: Maus pass auf!
Description:
From back of box

Sniff, sniff ... it smells like cheese! 
Oskar, the cheeky mouse creeps closer to outwit the cheese. 
but alas, the mousecatcher lies in wait! 
He tries to catch the mouse before he reaches his goal. 
Who wins - mouse or mousecatcher?

The purpose of the game is to prevent the other player from reaching the mouse hole. This can be done Oscar the "sneaky" little mouse, and his sister, Lilly, sit in their mouse apartment drinking tea. "Sniff, sniff...," something smells like cheese! From the church kitchen over the stairs, the smell of cheese fill the whole apartment. Will they try to "sneak" a piece of cheese? Will they be caught by the mouse catcher?"

One player plays the mouse who is trying to get to a square with the cheese without getting caught. The mouse moves by rolling a custom die that has a one, two, three and a X on it. Once the player has moved, the mouse catcher rolls the die and places that many red gates around the mouse trying to trap it. The game ends when either the mouse has gotten to the cheese or the mouse catcher has trapped the mouse.

Name: Kuckucksei
Description:
Content: 7 nests out of natural material, 1 color die, many colored wooden eggs

5 different games may be played with the material:
"Kuckuck, Kuckuck", "Schlafender Kuckuck", "Welche Hand?", "Hände unterm Tuch" and "Grün für den Kuckuck" (cooperative)

Name: Mein erstes Naturspiel: Woher kommt mein Essen?
Description:
Contents: 35 picture cards, 7 wooden stones

Bread, cheese, honey, rice, sugar, chocolate and apple juice - you ate and drank those food before. Do you know how those foods are produced?
All 35 picture cards are laid face down on the table. Now everyone tries to find the cards of each food ranked rank from 1-5 and then lay them down face up near the correct wooden play stone. The player who lays down the last card in a row earns the stone. The most stones determines the winner.

Name: Skat Cat
Description:
Caution - Skate Cat is coming!

Quick, Save your tons! Otherwise The crazy cat pushes them away! 7 tons on one another! Sounds easy!
Skate Cat runs like mad into your tons to destroy the towers.
Skate Cat is an electronic game figure. It reacts by sounds like "Skate Cat"! Then the skate board runs across the game field.
The players who could save his ton tower wins the game.

Name: Garten Kunterbunt
Description:
Content: 16 wooden tiles, 30 carrots

Two game ideas tell us how home fruit and vegetables look like and how it is called.

Game 1: Garten Kunterbunt: He who knows where the garden fruit grow and he who can react very fast, collects the most carrots and wins the game.

Game 2: Mein Bupfel ist: He who guesses which fruit is chosen by another child will get a carrot as his/her earnings.

Name: Bursa
Description:
Each player buys and sells stocks in this educational financing game, trying to accomplish her secret mission.  You get only 20 trade opportunities to make your millions!

Awards

2007 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Japanese Game

Name: Régence
Description:
In Parbourg, a city of the Bolro kingdom, the mayor as quit. His team takes over the city, and in 5 days the Duc of Umbourg will officially give the keys to a new mayor chosen from the team.
Each player plays a member of the team. Each day they try to show that they must be chosen as new mayor. They thus have 4 days before the Duc arrives to prove their superiority in the four categories of challenges: Politic, Military, Intelligence and Science.

Home Page: http://www.gdjeux.com/regence/index.php

Name: Axis & Allies: War at Sea – Task Force Booster Pack
Description:
This is an expansion to Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea.

From the website:
Add firepower to your fleets with the first expansion set for Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures! 
Task Force plows through the waves with several famous vessels & aircraft plus Canadian and Dutch units.

Task Force vessels include:


    Unique ships—such as the aircraft carriers USS Yorktown and German Graf Zeppelin—feature their distinctive markings. 
    Debut of Canadian unit -- HMCS Haida DD 
    Debut of Dutch unit -- De Ruyter CA 


Expands:

    Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea


Expanded by:

    Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea Flank Speed

Name: Ach, du Mauseschreck!
Description:
Players roll a die to determine how many spaces to move an elephant or the mouse. If a lone elephant encounters the mouse, it is sent back to the starting square. Be the first to reach the elephant temple with two elephants.

Contents: game board, mouse pawn, 12 elephants (in 4 colors), 1 die

Name: Zauberhut
Description:
"As soon as the magician leaves, the little apprentices zip up the stairs to the larder . There the invisible chocolate is stored!  The suspicious magician, however , has taken precautions and dressed up six stone guardians there. Only by wearing the magic hat can someone enter the larder and have a bite of the chocolate."

Players try to steal the magic hat from each other and carry it to the goal. Movement is dictated by tile draws.

Contents: 4 apprentice pawns, 1 big magic hat, 6 stone guardian tiles (with 1 to 6 dots), 1 game board consisting of 4 parts.

Name: Würfelwurm
Description:
"The aim of the game is to be the first to collect three shamrocks. When the caterpillar die is rolled, many different colors appear. If you have a good memory and uncover the cards in the right order, you receive a shamrock as a reward."

Contents: 1 caterpillar die, 11 shamrocks, 16 cards

Name: Piraten-Joe
Description:
Don't be the last to perform the action indicated by the die roll (such as clapping when the cannon icon is rolled), or you have to draw a scar on your face. Make a mistake and you get a scar, too! Five scars and you're out!

Contents: 4 eye patches, 4 gold coins, 1 pirate die, 1 make-up pencil.

Name: Bump 'N' Run
Description:
Bump 'N' Run - the Extreme Auto Racing Game!

NASCAR Fans get ready...Bump 'N' Run is a fast paced game that brings the excitement of auto racing right into your living room!

All the standard rules of racing apply: First you race for poll position. Then when the green flag goes down, your off around the track racing 10 laps to the finish line. On the way you will encounter caution flags, oil on the track, and maybe even get into a crash or two. Pit stops and a Mandatory Caution are sure to add even more suspense to the race. Though you may be the first to cross the finish line, you haven't won Bump & Run until your vehicle passes inspection!

Name: Forts
Description:
All is not peaceful in Fortland. Each country on the square-shaped continent is preparing an army to conquer their neighbors. The only problem is that their neighbors have armies invading their countries as well! The only answer is to build forts.

On each player's turn, that player rolls a six-sided die. The result is the number of actions their army must take this turn. Actions include marching, turning, building forts, and tearing down forts. The army must use all their actions during their turn, although they may be used in any order.

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Gridlock
Description:
Players take turns placing their pyramids on an 8x8 grid (chessboard). Then players in turn, drop pieces, placing them on their side facing away from them. If the pyramid is still facing away from them at the end of the game, they earn points for it, depending on size. When a piece is dropped, it can "turn" one or more other pieces - that is, change the direction of other pieces along the path in which it is pointing, so that those pieces are also pointing away from the player who dropped the piece. The number of pieces a piece can turn is dependent upon its size; a large pyramid can turn three other pieces, a medium two, and a small piece only one.

On your turn, you choose a piece to drop, and then you turn the correct number of pieces in front of the piece you just dropped, so that they are all pointing away from you.

However: only pieces that are lying down are turned. Pieces that are standing upright are left standing upright. This means that in some cases, particularly early in the game, you won't get to turn any pieces even if you drop a large piece.

Rules can be found on Wunderland.com

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Leaning Towers
Description:
Players stack pyramids, not allowing them to touch more pieces than the number of pips on the piece.

* Each player must place a piece of a different size than the previous placement. (The first piece placed on the Foundation is not affected by this rule.)
  * The point of one piece cannot touch the inside point of another piece
  * A piece can be placed on top of another piece as long as it does not violate these rules
  * Pieces must be placed with one hand
  * A player cannot touch any pieces other than one the being placed (unless reassembling after a break)

More information can be found on the Icehouse Wiki or on the designer's site.

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Hungry Harry
Description:
Hungry Harry makes use of the game box as a stand to place the score tray in and stand Hungry Harry up.
The idea is for players to take turns taking aim and throwing the balls into Hungry Harrys mouth and they are then fired from his guns and into the scoring tray.  Players score 1 for a red hole, 2 for blue and 3 for green.
There are various ways to play the game and these are explained in the rules.

Name: Die Mäuse-Bande
Description:
Content: board, 5 pieces of cheese, 6 colored disks, 1 colored die

A whoopee for the mice: they are alone and undisturbed in the pantry...together with a big piece of cheese high up on the shelf... Which mouse is able to get 2 pieces of cheese down from the shelf first?

Name: Four Crossings of the Chishui River
Description:
This wargame is the second in the Oriental Flagship Company's "Red Memories" series.  (The Nanchang Rebellion is the first in the series.)  The game is a simulation of a famous campaign in the Chinese Civil War.  The player controlling the Communist units deploys and moves secretly on a small magnetic board, while the Kuomintang player's units are visible, though face down, on the main board.

The game's Chinese name is &#22235;&#28193;&#36196;&#27700;&#12290;

Name: The Pony Game
Description:
(from the rulebook)
The Pony Game is like Monopoly.  Instead of buying property, houses and hotels, the setting is the world of horses.  You can own, rent, buy and sell stables and horses.

Contents
money
40 quiz cards
40 horse documents
40 horse labels
4 stable documents
4 playing pieces
2 dice

Name: Versus
Description:
Players try to score the most points by moving pieces they control to the central marked hexagons on the board. The VERSUS piece of each player can be used to block or convert the opponent's pieces.

The first edition is limited to 300 copies.

Name: Persiflage
Description:
From the designer:

The game that has certain elements of such well-known games as dominos, liar's dice and bridge but with new limitations placed on the tiles and on the procedure. The game is played on a board having seven hexagonal areas of the same size, each being subdivided into six equilateral triangles of the same size, and thirty-six tiles of the same size which are shaped to overlie and fill the equilateral triangular areas.

The seven hexagonal areas are arranged such that one is in the center and the others are distributed around it, each having one side contiguous with the side of the centrally located hexagonal area and two sides which are contiguous with two other hexagonal areas. The tiles are formed in six groups, each group having a different distinctive surface marking which can be used for bidding and playing procedures.

Name: Querulon
Description:
Players roll dice to place pawns on a board. Pawns are lined up towards the centre. The  first player to reach the centre with his pawns wins the game. The dice determine whether you can place your own pawns or remove those of others.
The rules claim it's a game full of tactics, but the dice completely determine what you're going to do.

Name: Det händer med händer
Description:
This is a Swedish educative game where the player learns how to use and converse through sign language. The game is divided in two different games that are played on the same board but with a different cards.

One of the games is called Teckenspelet (the sign game), where one player takes a card with a picture of a person preforming a sign, and imitates it. Then the other players then tries to guess what the sign means.

The other game is called Meningsspelet (the sentence game). In this game you use the cards to create short sentences. This is done by small images of the sentence on the cards, with numbers telling where in the sentence they should be.

Name: Huaiquiman y Tolosa 2
Description:
In  Huaiquiman y Tolosa players receive objective cards. Each card shows different characters and the places of the board where they should be.

In a turn, a player can move two of the six characters, trying to reach their objective and gain the victory points the card gives.  But this is not easy, since the next player can move the characters in the opposite direction.  
You can also gain victory points when someone fulfills their objective on your turn, in which case both players share their points.  
There are also action cards that can change everything in a second.

The first player reaching 20 points wins the game.

This game was developed for the second season of the TV Show of the same name, and the situations are a reflect of the ones happening in each chapter.

Name: Die drei ??? Kids: Das Schloss-Geheimnis
Description:
Story: The three ??? kids find 16 burglar-proof doors in a castle. What might be hidden behind them? With luck and combination, the players are able to open the doors, and find a treasure map. Who will get moist coins from the treasure chest?

The playing area consists of 16 cardboard doors. Each one gets a cardboard "lock" attached randomly, which shows tree colored dots. The player in turn tries to open one of the locks by rolling 3 color dice. If necessary, he may re-roll some or all dice up to two times. In addition, one die shows some sides that act as wild card, or hurt the leader.

If the player matches the colors of a lock, he turns over that door. The back shows a part of the treasure map, along with 1-3 coins, which he collects. Goal is to have most coins at game end, when all doors are opened and the map is complete.

Name: Cinemasters
Description:
From the publisher:
...the "reel" fan's trivia game.
A movie trivia game for fans of almost all ages.

After watching thousands of movies, you decide that it's time you appeared on screen. You study films. You audition roles. You succeed. You fail. Finally, you get the part you've been after! Will you get your name in lights and become immortal on the screen?

Move along the game board on your road to fame and fortune by answering questions about all those movies you loved and you hated. What makes the Cinemasters game unique is it contains over 120 different categories of questions with over 2,000 questions.

Name: Die wilden Fussballkerle: Bolzplatz
Description:
Story: Willi the coach hurries the team along the show-jumping course. To become fit, the players race to be the first to reach the finish line with his three members. But the trainer not only looks at his stop watch, he also has integrated some obstacles. Only a player who reacts quickly and keeps his nerves can win the game.

The game includes a board (two-sided) with an obstacle course and a shortcut, three team members per player, a die, and a timer. The timer gets started, and the active player tries to race his pieces along the track. He rolls the die, moves one of his characters the full amount, rolls the die again, moves the same or a different character, and so on until the time runs out. Then the next player gets to act.

The track depicts barrels which act as obstacles; no player can land on such a space. The characters of other players are either treated as obstacles, or moved back to the next free spot if somebody lands on their space. The finish space needs to be reached with an exact die roll. The player who first finishes the race first with all his characters wins the game.

Name: Taiko! Samurai Warfare During the Age of the Country at War
Description:
Taiko! recreates the command and control methods of the samurai warlord, who, in the period covered by these rules, typically led from the rear where he could keep a watchful eye on the proceedings of the battle. While he can join the fray (perhaps to bolster the flagging morale of one of his units), his ability to control the rest of his army will suffer, maybe evening failing to follow his orders.

Written with 15mm figures in mind, Taiko! converts easily to 6mm and 25mm as well.  The rules play to two levels of combat, 1:1 scale, and 50:1 scale. The former is used for small skirmish battles, and has a fast and chaotic feel to it as units of warriors engage, pursue their beaten foe, and then perhaps find themselves being beaten and pursued.  The 50:1 scale is ideal for recreating the larger battles of feudal and/or renaissance Japan, with large formations of infantry and cavalry maneuvering around the battlefield under the control of their lord or one of his generals.

Name: Giggling Elmo's Hot Tomato Game
Description:
Game contains:
1 Plush Elmo Hot Tomato
20 Hot Tomato game cards: 6 letter cards, 6 color cards and 8 category cards.

Form a circle and start the Elmo Hot Tomato giggling.  Pass Elmo to the next player.  If Elmo stops giggling while your holding him you're out.  The last player left in the game wins.

For more advanced play players must call out words in a category before passing Elmo.  Use the cards or make up your own categories: rhyming words, family names, board games, etc.

Name: Swiss Quiz
Description:
In Swiss Quiz, players will read statements concerning Switzerland and will have to vote whether these are true or false...

For each correct vote, the players will move their pawns toward their ultimate goal : the edelweiss !

A token-betting system enables players who take risk at the right time to advance faster if their answer is correct.

Name: Song of Wind and Water
Description:
From the publisher:

You can defeat a dragon, but can you take on mother nature?  The second expansion in the Song of Blades and Heroes line introduces rules for fighting in inclement weather and hostile environments.  From snow storms to cursed ruins, from rivers to volcanoes, your battlefield will never look the same.  Includes a color map and a complete wilderness survival campaign.
Families: Series: Song of Blades and Heroes

Name: CrunchTime
Description:
CrunchTime means the last few minutes of the game, when the big plays are made... with the game "ON THE LINE!"

CrunchTime is a new and exciting, action-packed basketball board game. Players face each other in a head-to-head, 12-minute timed, quick pace game. The play goes back and forth like real basketball: fast breaks, fade away J's, slam-dunks, fouls, steals, rebounds, and those game-changing 3 pointers! Combine all of that b-ball fun with rolling the dice, moving your pawns, placing the foul chips, marking your score, watching the clock and spinning the spinner (for fouls and 3's)! Lots of variety and action!

Name: El Gran Comercio Ripley
Description:
It’s a Monopoly kind of game, but featuring stores from different brands present in Chile instead of Streets.
Also, the fortune cards are in the shape of Ripley Store Credit Card

Name: Leibstandarte Pack 2: Barbarossa!
Description:
This is the second of 4 scenario packs that follows the 1st SS Panzer Division, Liebstandarte Adolf Hitler through World War II. These scenarios focus on the opening of Germany's invasion of Russia June-November 1941.

These scenarios are compatible with MMP’s ASL System.

The scenarios are:

LSSAH #9: Forest Through the Trees
North of Miropol Russia, 8 July 1941

LSSAH #10: Baptism of Fire
Henrykowka, Russia, 13 July 1941

LSSAH #11: Sea Battle
Cherson, Russia 19 August 1941

LSSAH #12: Contact!
Hurde, Russia 20 September 1941

LSSAH #13: The Russians are coming!
Swobodny Port, Russia, 21 September 1941

LSSAH #14: A Bird in the Hand...
Romanowka, Russia, 6 October 1941

LSSAH #15: Shot off with too Weak of a Bullet
South of Balka Tschaptschach, Russia, 26 October 1941

LSSAH #16: A Grim Day at Karasny Krim
Karsny Krim, Russia, 20 November 1941

Expands

    Advanced Squad Leader

Name: Action at Carentan!
Description:
This expansion contains four tournament style scenarios set on the outskirts of Carentan during the invasion of Normandy.  The scenarios follow the 101st 'Screaming Eagles' Parachute Division during the first week of the invasion.  In addition to the four scenarios, this expansion pack also includes a small unmounted map which all four scenarios play on.

The four scenarios are:

    AaC #1: Cole's Charge - North of Carentan, France, 10 June 1944
    AaC #2: The Cabbage Patch - Along the Causeway to Carentan, France, 6 June 1944
    AaC #3: Green Devils - Outside Carentan, France, 13 June 1940
    AaC #4: Cooperation Reigns - Outside Carentan, France, 13 June 1940


These scenarios are compatible with MMP's ASL System.

Name: From the Cellar: Pack 1
Description:
This scenario pack contains ten color scenarios designed by the publishers at La Franc-Tireur. Scenario #49 may be combined with #47 & #48 from Le Franc-Tireur Issue #8 to form a campaign game.

Also included with the pack is a small overlay sheet containing 2 overlays.  The overlays are FT4 and FT5.

These scenarios are compatible with Avalon Hill's / MMP’s ASL System.

The scenarios are:

FT #49: Lingevres - Aftermath: Lingevres, France, 16 June 1944
FT #50: Meeting on the Summit: Mont Froid, France, 6th April 1945
FT #51: Harmless Steel: Raseinai, Russia, 24 June 1941
FT #52: Bouchon A Bouchon: Bouchain, France, 25 May 1940
FT #53: First Drop: Gorki (North West of Mogilev), 14 July 1941
FT #54: The Wisps Come and Go: Menil 3 Fetus Farm, France, 4 June 1940
FT #55: Finnish Blitzkrieg: Near Alakurtti, Finland, 24 August 1941
FT #56: Primo Contatto: Pokrovskoje, Russia, 11 August 1941
FT #57: Wysoka Mountain: Wyoka, Poland, 2nd Sept 1939
FT #58: Dream is Over: Le Mesnil Adelee, France, 7 August 1944

See Also:

    From the Cellar: Pack 2
    From the Cellar: Pack 3

Name: Home Golf
Description:
From the Publisher's site:

The world’s most realistic golf game for the whole family.

Home Golf is a board game where you play golf like you do on a real course.
A 9-hole golf course with activity and fun for the whole family.
You choose direction and target for your ball using one of the 4 different golfers.

Nothing is accidental. It is all up to you and you don’t need golf experience.

Name: HOB Update: SS I / SS II
Description:
This scenario pack subtitled "SS I No Quarter, No Glory / SS II Führer's Firemen", is an update for the out of print scenario packs Waffen SS: No Quarter No Glory and Waffen SS: Fuhrer's Firemen.  This pack contains 14 scenarios that have been updated with the errata and tweaked for play balance.

Unlike the original scenario packs, this publication does not include any counter sheets.  The counter sheets that were included in the original scenario packs were deemed too similar to the AH/MMP counter art, and is part of the reason why the original scenario packs are no longer in print.

This scenario pack is compatible with the AH/MMP ASL Game System, and components from that game system are required to play these scenarios.

Scenarios: NQNG 1 to 6, FF 7 to 14

Name: Gushers 'n Dusters
Description:
Gushers 'n Dusters is an educational game about the petroleum industry and the risks and challenges of exploring for oil and gas. Designed for middle and high school students...

In addition to providing insight into important elements of the petroleum industry, Gushers 'n Dusters presents concepts of geology and economics. Through role play and strategy development, players come to understand basic scientific and entrepreneurial principles while...enjoying fun-filled competition and risk-taking.

Whether they play oil company executives, drilling company specialists, or shrewd bankers, students learn about the free enterprise system and confront the need to respond to national energy shortages in the hypothetical nation of Kortu.

Game parts include map board of Kortu, study prints, practice boards, drilling boards, seismic surveys, drilling rig and lots of play money.

Name: Gulliver's Travels
Description:
No. 293 in Piatnik's line of card games, the cards contain scenes and passages from Jonathan Swift's novel, Gulliver's Travels.  The game consists of 36 game cards plus one card with the rules: 20 of the cards deal with Gulliver's journey to Lilliput, and the other 16 to Brobdingnag.

The cards are illustrated on one side, with the relevant passage from the novel on the back.  The cards are marked with numbers from 1-9 and letters from a-d: 1a, 1b, 1c, 1d, 2a, etc.  Every four cards with the same number are a set.  The story is told sequentially from card to card, obviously heavily abbreviated.

The game is a simple "Go Fish" variant, but oddly enough they recommend gambling when playing the game!  ("A pool of counters formed at the start pays an agreed bonus to the player with the most fours.  A stipulated fine may be paid to the player who is misinformed about a card.")  The game does not include any "counters" ...

The cards are completely in English, despite being made in Austria.

Name: From the Cellar: Pack 2
Description:
The second Advanced Squad Leader scenario pack from Le Franc-Tireur. Though the publisher is French, all the scenarios are in English and are printed in color.  The inside back of the game folder contains errata for issues of Le Franc-Tireur 6-10.

This pack contains 10 scenarios covering the war in Europe spanning the period from June 1940 through May 1945. There are a wide variety of scenarios here using French, British, American, Slovakian, Partisan, Italian German and Russian units.

The scenarios are:

FT69: Durs a Cuire: Poix/Thieulloy-L'Abbaye crossroad, France, 6 June 1940
FT70: Ride across the Caucus: Near, Kutaskaya, USSR, 28 September 1942
FT71: The Last Circle: Titomnik, USSR, 13 January 1943
FT72: Catcher Caught: Leskovicz, Albania, 27 June 1943
FT73: The Adiratic Pirates: Milna, Bac Island, Yugoslavia, 21 October 1943
FT74: Freeing the Roadway: Crepon, France, 6 June 1944
FT75: Unexpected Fire: South of Cristot, France, 11 June 1944
FT76: White Suns: Near Mantes, France, 23 August 1944
FT77: Suprised Buffalo: Vergemoli, Italy, 26 December 1944
FT78: The War is Over: Near Ferlach, Austria, 11 May 1945

See Also:

    From the Cellar: Pack 1
    From the Cellar: Pack 3

Name: Dirty Deutsch
Description:
A card game for 2 to 8 players, who are old enough to know all the swear words already.

Contents: 96 full-color insult cards, 3 board cards, and rules for play.

Dirty Deutsch is an uncouth romp through the taboo, where no insult is too callous or low.  Players swap German words and phrases to construct the perfect put down.  Don’t know any German?  Don’t worry.  That’s what the game is for.

The cards are color-coded for vulgarity, so you always know whether you are being charmingly irreverent or begging for a beat-down.

Players match colors and collect 20 points to win.

Home Page: http://www.DirtyDeutsch.com

Name: The Table Cricket Game
Description:
The Table Cricket Game is played (as noted in the rules) "...as per the rules of real one-day limited over cricket." The batsman draws cards from a deck and the fielder places his pawns on the spaces on the board marked by dots, such as "silly point" and "midoff." The batsman then plays his cards one after the other, and tallies his runs. Each card has a type of hit (such as "Full-blooded drive to Mid-on") as well as a F and NF section, showing how many runs would be scored if the fielder has placed a pawn there (F for "fielder") or if there is no fielding pawn there (NF for "no fielder"). Scores are tabulated on the score sheet pads.

No publisher or designer was listed on the box.

Name: Cricket
Description: Cricket as produced by Panther Enterprises in Sri Lanka is a simple re-theming of Snakes and ladders. Instead of snakes, however, there are squares for "bowled" and "stumped." Instead of ladders, the player may land on a "sixer" or "boundary" square and advance that number of "runs." Otherwise, it is a simple roll and move game.

Name: Das Geheimnis der Erfolgreichen
Description:
Triva game with a 'Success'-theme. Players need several abilities - e.g. luck, knowledge, teamplay - to win this game.

Be the first obtaining a (coloured) card of each area (totally 5);
roll the die and move your token (you may roll again once, if you are not pleased with the result);
depending on the space you landed on you must perform an action:
1. Green: Active player draws a card and reading the green question - all other players make short notices/remarks about it (hidden);
active player has to assign answers to players - successful? If yes get a green pyramid.
2. Grey: Use your sawy! Find correct answer to a question within a minute - you may ask for assistance (one person only).
Example: Find the correspondent city in Europe with the letters R_I_M_D_D_A; successful (correct answers on the back of the card)? You and your partner will collect a grey pyramid.
3. Blue: find within 30 s (with or without a partner) correct answer; example: How many wings does a dragonfly have? 
4. Red: Describe within 60 s together with a player of your choice - word after word - searched term, e.g. opera; successful... get a red pyramid.
5. Golden: All players form their own 'five-digit' number. Push your luck - shuffle 10 numbered cards (0 - 9), draw 5 out of them and turn them over step by step. After each step players have to make up their decisions placing this digit. Highest number wins a golden pyramid.
6. Coloured: your choice
7. White: steal a pyramid of your choice from another player 
8. Ending a full circuit: get a pyramid of your choice
TRADING RATE: 2 pyramids (same colour) = 1 card (same colour)

Name: That's Truckin'
Description:
Players get paid for delivering freight. The object of the game is to be the first player to pay for his or her truck, that is, to reach $40,000.00.

Players select from a hand of load sheets, which indicate i) where a player picks up a load, ii) where that load is to be delivered, iii) the fee for delivering the load, and iv) the bonus fee if the load is delivered within a certain number of days. A day is a player's turn. The roll of a die determines how far a player may travel on his turn. A player's truck may carry up to two loads at one time.

The key to the game is in the efficient use of the load sheets. For example, do you take just one load across country and go for that big bonus, or do you double up on the loads, which will slow you down and probably cost you a bonus, but will give you an extra payday? You also try to minimize the travel time in which the truck is empty by arranging for the next pick up to be near the just-reached destination.

Name: The Flea Market Game
Description:
"Take a trip to the flea market... shop for all of your favorite things."

Players move around a colorful monopoly-style flea market board as they collect items in categories like antiques, clothing, and jewelry. The first player to collect all 6 tokens and fill up their box on the board, wins.

Includes game board, 4 tokens, 8 dice, 24 game pieces, storage insert, and instructions.

Name: Two's Golf / 2's Wild
Description:
The box contains two games.

TWO'S GOLF shares some features similar to the much more recently released Box of Golf.  The score sheet consists of 18 hole, each consisting of 22 spaces.  The first space is the tee, the last space represents Out of Bound, and the remaining 20 in between are either various hazards (water, shrubs, sand), fairway, or the flag.  The flag is usually between spaces 8 and 20, depending on the length and par of the hole.

To begin a hole, you must pick up the number of dice corresponding to your first choice for a club (3 for driver, 2 for iron, 1 for putter, 1 for sand wedge).  Ball movement is determined by the sum of the dice rolled.  Continue on making a new club selection, taking a swing, and marking off the ball movement until it lands in the hole.

The six-sided dice in game are all identical: 1, 1, 2, 2*, 3, 3.  The asterisk gives you the ability to double the sum of the dice roll.

2'S WILD is a Yahtzee clone specifically designed to take advantage of the dice for TWO'S GOLF.  Five dice are used for the various scoring combinations.  There are score pads included for that game as well.

Name: Scrabble: The Simpsons Edition
Description:
This is a Simpsons-themed version of Scrabble with a variant board, 10 special action tiles with Simpsons character, and additional words and names from the Simpsons made legal with bonus points for spelling them.

This was an exclusive for the Borders chain of US bookstores. It is completely distinct from the Scrabble: Simpsons Edition published by Mattel in the UK. A file with information on the differences between the editions is located at that game's entry.

Name: Backaro
Description:
From game's manual:

"Backaro was inspired by the thousand year old classic Backgammon and is played in a similar manner but with a few marked differences. The name Backaro means as much as 'back in the round'. The players have to bring their discs back into their designated area, in order to bear them off. For experienced Backgammon players there is a set of quick rules."

Name: Murder à la carte: Murder by Candlelight
Description:
Another entry in the Murder A La Carte series of murder mystery party games.

It is 1848.  The Dowage Lady Withering is found dead at the stately home Withering Depths on the Torkshire Moors.  The famous withering jewels are missing.  Those present at the dinner party include the murderer:
Lord Selby Withering
Sir Clifforde Heath-Clifforde
Suzanna Heath-Clifforde
Emily Lloyd Bridges
Lady Caroline Mouton
Reverend Adam Brethren
Jane Eyrie
Carlos Chickensi

Name: The Royals Trivia Board Game
Description: 1,200 questions about the Monarchy from the past, present and from fact to fiction.

Name: Lingo
Description:
Lingo is a word game played with interlocking tiles.  Players take turns removing a single tile from the dispenser and placing it in the pool.  Any player can then call a word, using the letters in pool, or a combination of letters in the pool plus an already completed word.  If this word is unchallenged, the player claims the tiles and joins them as a word in his play area.  In this way, players can 'steal' a word from another player.

At the end of the game, players join all their words together.  The player with the longest 'word stick' is declared the winner.

The dispenser is then used as a 'word breaker', as the sticks are fed into a slot and broken apart, ready for the next game.

Name: Dynamite
Description:
Dynamite is a fun game for those seeking an hour of joy, tension and fun.
At the beginning of the game a "Time Bomb" is set to explode in 30 seconds. each player must put a card from his hand thus reducing the time left by number on the cards.
Special cards allow to delay the explosion by adding 5 minutes or forcing the next player to put 2 cards!
As the countdown approaches zero the tension is rising.

Name: Dumbass! expansion #1
Description:
A ten-card supplement for Dumbass!. Or a thousand cards. Your choice. Using an Infinite Armies-like interface, you can enter any text, icon or border combination you want to each of the ten cards (including Secrets), and when you print them they will be indistinguishable from those in the main game.

It's billed as the only Dumbass! supplement you'll ever need...

Expands:

    Dumbass!
